page.title: 12THE BIRMINGHAM CANAL
page.content: The canal links Oldbury to Birmingham and Wolverhampton. It was built originally for carrying coal, but is only used now for recreational purposes. It has an average depth of three feet and can take barges with a beam of six feet. The sides were lined with brick and the bottom was of puddled clay. The boatyard in Oldbury, builds between five and six boats each year. The boats measure some seventy feet by six feet and are built of mild sheet steel which is cut and welded to shape. Each boat costs around Â£20,000 to build. The Titford canal also runs through the Oldbury area. This has several flights of locks for the boats to navigate through.
